qas.question: What was the name of the area in which youth played and exercised?
What could you also call Rome's Campus Maritus?
What is the Roman board game Tabula a precursor to?
What was Roman version of Chess called?

context: The city of Rome had a place called the <a0_0>Campus Martius<a0_0/> ("<a1_0>Field of Mars<a1_0/>"), which was a sort of drill ground for Roman soldiers. Later, the Campus became Rome's track and field playground. In the campus, the youth assembled to play and exercise, which included jumping, wrestling, boxing and racing.[citation needed] Equestrian sports, throwing, and swimming were also preferred physical activities.[citation needed] In the countryside, pastimes included fishing and hunting.[citation needed] Board games played in Rome included dice (Tesserae or Tali), Roman Chess (<a3_0>Latrunculi<a3_0/>), Roman Checkers (Calculi), Tic-tac-toe (Terni Lapilli), and Ludus duodecim scriptorum and Tabula, predecessors of <a2_0>backgammon<a2_0/>. Other activities included chariot races, and musical and theatrical performances.[citation needed]
